channel.title: Too2s on CityU-Bioinformatics
channel.description: Recent content in Too2s on CityU-Bioinformatics

item.description: Table of Contents Metabolic profiles analysis Metabolic Network analysis mGWAS Metabolite enrichment analysis MS-based untargeted Metabolomics Metabolic Network analysis mGWAS Metabolite enrichment analysis NMR-based Metabolomics/MS-based targeted metabolomics Spectral corrections Spectral deconvolution Chemometric analysis Metabolite identification Metabolic profiles analysis The further development of spectroscopic and spectrometric tools for high throughput analyses of selected biochemical pathways is crucial to the acquisition of metabolome data sets of sufficient quality for metabonomics and metabolomics.

item.title: DNA Modifications
item.description: Table of Contents DNA modification analysis DNA Methylation Prediction DNA Methylation Deconvolution DNA methylation array analysis Differential Methylation Site Detection Differential Methylation region Detection Enrichment Analysis Over-representation analysis Gene set enrichment analysis Topology enrichment analysis Bisulfite Sequencing Data Analysis (BS-seq analysis) Differential Methylation region Detection Methylation Annotation EWAS DNA modification analysis Whole genome DNA methylation detection is one of the most important part of epigenetics research.

item.title: Genome Annotation
item.description: Table of Contents Genome Annotation Gene Ontology Annotation BLASTX Blast2GO GO Semantic Similarity Analysis G-SESAME | Gene Semantic Similarity Analysis and Measurement Tools clusterProfiler | GO semantic similarity analysis : Genome annotation GOToolBox | GO semantic similarity analysis : DNA sequence analysis SML-Toolkit | Semantic Measures Library Toolkit Promoter Predication FirstEF | First Exon Finder CpGpromoter PROmiRNA Annotation Workflows RAST | Rapid Annotation using Subsystem Technology Prokka | Annotation workflows BlastKOALA Find more tools: OMIVTOOLS Genome Annotation Genome annotation is a key process for identifying the coding and non-coding regions of a genome, gene locations and functions.

item.title: Prediction of Protein Structure
item.description: This part may contains the following tools: (Will be filled in the future) Primary structure ProtParam COILS Secondary structure PredictProtein PSIPRED tertiary structure Phyre Swiss-PdbViewer citation

item.title: RNA Transcription
item.description: Table of Contents Transcription analysis Lipidomics Databases MS-based untargeted lipidomics MS-based targeted lipidomics Transcription analysis Transcript abundance is in many ways an extraordinary phenotype, with special attributes that confer particular importance on an understanding of its genetics. The primary transformative potential of genome-wide gene expression genetics is the sheer number of traits — thousands — that can be assayed simultaneously. Lipidomics Databases Development of databases and the related bioinformatics tools has become an essential part of the omics studies.

item.title: RNA Transcription
item.description: Table of Contents Transcription analysis Prognostic Biomarker Identification Region Discrimination Gene co-expression prediction Gene regulatory network inference Gene set enrichment analysis Over-representation analysisi RNA-seq analysis Read count Known transcript quantification Gene fusion detection Prognostic biomarker identification Differential expression Alternative splicing events identification CAGE Analysis TSS detection De novo motif discovery Gene expression array analysis Differential expression detection Time course Meta-analysis Metatranscriptomic sequencing analysis Prediction-base Taxonomic Homology-Based Taxonomic Transcription analysis Transcript abundance is in many ways an extraordinary phenotype, with special attributes that confer particular importance on an understanding of its genetics.

item.title: DNA Structure
item.description: Table of Contents DNA Structure Shape prediction do_x3dna 3DNA DINAMelt DNAshape R-loop forming sequence prediction QmRLFS-finder DNA Structure Database R-loopDB | R-loop forming sequence databases Small-angle Scattering AXES FoXS AquaSAXS Find more tools: OMIVTOOLS DNA Structure DNA molecules exist in many different conformations, including A-DNA, B-DNA, or Z-DNA forms, which depend on the nucleotide sequence, hydratation level, presence of metal ions, etc.

item.title: Low-level RNA detection
item.description: Table of Contents DNA modification analysis Low-level RNA detection scRNA-seq analysis Noise reduction Transcript quantification Cell lineage and pseudotime inference Dimensionality reduction Single-cell qPCR dPCR DNA modification analysis Whole genome DNA methylation detection is one of the most important part of epigenetics research. It is supposed to have a great effect on cancers and tumors, and even be involved in the senility of human.

item.title: Nucleosome Positioning
item.description: Table of Contents Nucleosome Positioning MNase-seq analysis ATAC-seq analysis Find more tools: OMIVTOOLS Nucleosome Positioning MNase-seq analysis The technology of micrococcal nuclease (MNase) digestion combined with high-throughput sequencing (MNase-seq) is a powerful method to map the genome-wide distribution of nucleosome occupancy (Mavrich et al., 2008; Schones et al., 2008; Jiang and Pugh, 2009). Source text: Chen et al., 2014. ATAC-seq analysis ATAC-seq allows simultaneous interrogation of factor occupancy, nucleosome positions in regulatory sites, and chromatin accessibility genome wide by considering the position of insertion and the distribution of insert lengths captured during the transposition reaction.

item.title: Protein Mass Spectrometry
item.description: This part may contains the following tools: (Will be filled in the future) X!Tandem Mascot Sequest TPP citation

item.title: DNA-Protein Interactions
item.description: Table of Contents HT-SELEX Analysis DNase-seq Analysis ChIP-seq Analysis De novo assembly Peak calling Differential peak calling De novo motif discovery DNA-binding proteins are proteins that have DNA-binding domains and thus have a specific or general affinity for single- or double-stranded DNA. Sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins generally interact with the major groove of B-DNA, because it exposes more functional groups that identify a base pair.

item.title: Genome Editing
item.description: Table of Contents Genome Editing CRISPR/Cas9 sgRNA Design CRISPR design GuideScan E-CRISP CRISPRscan TALEN design TALE-NT TALEN Targeter ZFN Design Zinc Finger Tools ZifNN ZFN-Site CRISPR/Cas9 Screen Analysis CREATE | CRISPR-enabled trackable genome engineering MAGeCK | Model-based Analysis of Genome-wide CRISPR/Cas9 Knockout MAGeCK-VISPR caRpools | CRISPR-AnalyzeR for pooled screens Genome Editing Database Find more tools: OMIVTOOLS Genome Editing Programmable nucleases - including zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs), transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs) and RNA-guided engineered nucleases (RGENs) derived from the bacterial clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)-Cas (CRISPR-associated) system - enable targeted genetic modifications in cultured cells, as well as in whole animals and plants.

item.title: Population Genomics
item.description: Table of Contents Popilation Genetic Analysis Pedigree Reconstruction Forward Simulation Population Structure Inference Genotyping by Sequencing data analysis (GBS Analysis) Base Callling Read Quality Contorl Adapter trimming Gerline SNO Detection Somatic SNV detection Restriction Site Associated DNA Sequencing Data Analysis (RAD-seq Analysis) Phylogenetic Inference SNP/SNV Annotation Population genomics is the large-scale comparison of DNA sequences of populations. Population genomics is a neologism that is associated with population genetics.

item.title: DNA-Protein Interactions
item.description: Table of Contents HT-SELEX Analysis DNase-seq Analysis ChIP-seq Analysis De novo assembly Peak calling Differential peak calling De novo motif discovery DNA-binding proteins are proteins that have DNA-binding domains and thus have a specific or general affinity for single- or double-stranded DNA. Sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins generally interact with the major groove of B-DNA, because it exposes more functional groups that identify a base pair.
